item.title: Outspoken South Korea Leftist Survived Stabbing on Path to Power
item.description: Lee Jae-myung, the tenacious left-leaning maverick on the brink of becoming South Korea’s next president, has spent a lifetime picking himself off the canvas to fight again.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, center left, and his wife Kim Hye-gyeong at the party’s election night event in Seoul on June 4.

item.title: US Farm Sentiment at 4-Year High as Trump Seeks Trade Deals
item.description: American farmer sentiment jumped to a four-year high, with growers betting on rising crop exports as the Trump administration pushes for more trade deals from Vietnam to Italy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Hirtzer, Erin Ailworth, Skylar Woodhouse

item.title: South Korea Elects Lee President, Capping Six Months of Chaos
item.description: South Korea’s opposition candidate Lee Jae-myung vowed to improve people’s livelihoods as his main rival acknowledged defeat in a presidential election that was largely a verdict on ousted leader Yoon Suk Yeol’s botched attempt to revive martial law after decades of democratic rule.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, presidential candidate for the Democratic Party, left, and his wife Kim Hye-gyeong at the party's election night event in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. With almost 95% of the ballots counted, Lee, a left-leaning former labor activist, had won 48.8% of the vote while the ruling People Power Party’s candidate Kim Moon-soo had 42.0%, according the National Election Commission, a narrower margin than indicated by an earlier exit poll.

item.title: Mexico Vote for Top Court Shows Majority With Morena Ties
item.description: Mexico’s new Supreme Court will feature a clear majority of justices with direct ties to the country’s former leftist president or the ruling Morena party he founded, according to preliminary election results with nearly all votes counted.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico's president, casts a ballot at a polling station during the judicial elections in Mexico City, Mexico, on Sunday, June 1, 2025. Mexican voters head to the polls on Sunday to begin picking judges in an unprecedented election that could give President Sheinbaum broad influence over a revamped judiciary, the only branch of government her party doesn't control.

item.title: Trump Asks Congress to Slash Funds for NPR, PBS and Foreign Aid
item.description: President Donald Trump asked lawmakers to cut more than $9 billion in funding for the Public Broadcasting Service, National Public Radio and foreign aid from this year’s budget, an attempt to write into law some of the so-called “DOGE cuts” initiated by Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The National Public Radio (NPR) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, May 5, 2025. President Donald Trump last week ordered an end to taxpayer subsidies for National Public Radio and the Public Broadcasting Service, a longstanding goal of some Republicans who have accused the media outlets of bias.

item.title: Credit Card Swipe Fee Fight Complicates Stablecoin Bill Passage
item.description: An effort by retailers and their allies in the Senate to mandate competition to Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. in credit card processing has complicated efforts to swiftly pass the stablecoin bill supported by the crypto industry and President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Paige Smith

media:content.media:description: Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. credit cards are arranged for a photograph in Tiskilwa, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, Sept. 18, 2018. Visa and Mastercard agreed to pay as much as $6.2 billion to end a long-running price-fixing case brought by merchants over card fees, the largest-ever class action settlement of an antitrust case.

item.title: Chinese Firms Brush Off US Tariff Risks With Domestic Confidence
item.description: When US President Donald Trump took aim at China with record tariffs, the country’s firms shrugged it off.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and a container ship at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. China and the US agreed to temporarily lower tariffs levied against each other's products — the first major de-escalation in the trade row that was touted by US President Donald Trump as a "total reset" of bilateral ties.

item.title: White House Memo on EV Grants Sets Up Fight Over Spending Power
item.description: The White House forcefully rejected a congressional watchdog’s opinion that found the Trump administration illegally delayed funding for electric vehicle infrastructure, setting the stage for a broader constitutional clash over federal spending powers.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: A Toyota Rav-4 Prime charges at a ChargePoint electric vehicle charging station in Hudson, New York, US, on Tuesday, Sept. 3, 2024. ChargePoint Holdings Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on September 4.

item.title: Trump Aide Hassett Reveals Coinbase Stake of at Least $1 Million
item.description: Kevin Hassett, one of President Donald Trump’s top economic officials, revealed holding a stake in Coinbase Global Inc. worth at least $1 million thanks to his work as an adviser for the US crypto exchange, according to his financial disclosure.
item.dc:creator: Bill Allison

media:content.media:description: Kevin Hassett, director of the National Economic Council, speaks to members of the media following a meeting with lawmakers at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Bessent and congressional Republicans are meeting to sketch out the plan for passing a multi-trillion tax cut in the coming weeks as polling shows that voters largely disapprove of the White House’s handling of the economy.

item.title: Trump Signs Order Hiking Steel, Aluminum Tariffs to 50%
item.description: President Donald Trump signed a directive on Tuesday raising steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% from 25% starting on June 4, following through on a pledge to boost import taxes to help domestic manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: A crane moves a roll of coiled steel at a steel plant in Hamilton, Ontario. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

item.title: Ecopetrol Spying Probe Adds Fuel to Colombia Corruption Storm
item.description: Colombian prosecutors are probing an Ecopetrol SA contract tied to surveillance of the company’s own executives, turning up pressure on CEO Ricardo Roa and President Gustavo Petro.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: Ricardo Roa

item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, White House correspondent Josh Wingrove looks at the president’s latest moves on tariffs. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

item.title: UK Rushes to Save US Steel Tariff Deal Before Levies Double
item.description: The UK is pushing the US to remove tariffs on British steel exports in line with a deal struck last month, ahead of a planned blanket doubling of levies.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: Molten steel at a plant in Sheffield, UK. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

item.title: Elon Musk Blasts Trump Tax Bill as Budget-Busting ‘Abomination’
item.description: Donald Trump ally Elon Musk lambasted the president’s signature tax bill as a budget-busting “abomination” as Republican fiscal hawks stepped up criticism of the massive fiscal package.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: Senator Rand Paul

item.title: UK Builders Still Able to Hire From Abroad Under Visa Clampdown
item.description: Construction workers from abroad will still be able to migrate to the UK despite tighter visa restrictions announced by the government, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said, as Labour attempts to slash migration without damaging critical sectors of the economy.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Max Harlow

media:content.media:description: A worker fixes scaffolding in to place on a partially completed house on a Bellway Plc housing estate in Bishops Stortford, UK, on Thursday, March 13, 2025. Interest-rate cuts, wage growth and stagnant home prices have begun to marginally improve affordability, boosting confidence that housing output will start to recover from the plunge offset by the end of the cheap-money era.

item.title: US Sent Letters to Trade Partners Ahead of Tariff Deadline
item.description: The Office of the US Trade Representative has sent letters to trading partners to remind them of an upcoming deadline in tariff negotiations, according to the White House, an effort by the Trump administration to push forward talks.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: The Office of the US Trade Representative seal before a signing ceremony with Katherine Tai, US trade representative, and Koji Tomita, Japan's ambassador to the US, for an agreement to increase the beef safeguard trigger level under the US-Japan Trade Agreement in Washington, D.C., US, on Thursday, June 2, 2022. The new safeguard mechanism will allow US exporters to meet Japan's growing demand for beef and reduce the probability that Japan will impose higher tariffs in the future, according to the Office of the US Trade Representative. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Política migratoria de Trump en EE.UU. depende de cárceles privadas
item.description: Cada vez son más las comunidades en EE.UU. que creen que su porvenir financiero depende de ofrecer servicios al ICE para encerrar a migrantes. Torrance County, Nuevo México, es una de ellas.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Adams-Heard, Polly Mosendz, Fola Akinnibi

media:content.media:description: Linda Jaramillo Photographer: Adam Golfer and TJ Proechel for Bloomberg Businessweek

item.title: UN Says 4 Million People Have Fled Sudan’s Civil War Since 2023
item.description: Four million people have fled Sudan since civil war broke out in 2023, the UN refugee agency said, warning that the influx of refugees was straining neighboring countries and posed a risk to regional and global security.
item.dc:creator: Sherif Tarek

media:content.media:description: A Sudanese army officer walks near an armoured vehicle seized after their capture of a base used by the rival Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitaries after the latter group evacuated from the Salha area of Omdurman, the twin-city of Sudan's capital, on May 26, 2025. Sudan, Africa's third largest country, has been ravaged by more than two years of war between the army and the RSF. The conflict has killed tens of thousands of people, displaced 13 million and created what the United Nations describes as the world's worst humanitarian crisis. (Photo by Ebrahim Hamid / AFP) (Photo by EBRAHIM HAMID/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Texas Wants to Kill a Cannabis Boom It Accidentally Helped Stoke
item.description: Texas is on the cusp of banning all recreational THC products after lawmakers passed a bill to reverse the unintended effects of hemp laws that led to a boom in shops selling gummies, joints, vapes and drinks that create a similar high to marijuana.
item.dc:creator: Joe Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Hemp plants.

item.title: Democratic Senators Want Bondi to Explain Crime Unit's Closure
item.description: The lawmakers gave Pam Bondi two weeks to respond to questions about the Justice Department’s plans to dissolve a unit tasked with dismantling organized crime networks and drug cartels.
item.dc:creator: Jason Leopold

media:content.media:description: Pam Bondi, US attorney general, center, speaks during a news conference at the Department of Justice (DOJ) in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 12, 2025. Bondi said Wednesday that the Justice Department has sued the state of New York and several officials over its immigration policies.

item.title: Trump to Attend June NATO Summit at The Hague, White House Says
item.description: Donald Trump will attend the upcoming North Atlantic Treaty Organization summit at The Hague, the White House said, as the US president seeks to rally the alliance’s members to step up defense spending.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Workers prepare the main meeting room ahead of the NATO summit in The Hague on May 22. Photographer: Koen Van Weel/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Dutch Prime Minister Gives Resignation, Takes Caretaker Role
item.description: Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof tendered his resignation and will continue in a caretaker role, setting the stage for a snap election.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom, Katharina Rosskopf

media:content.media:description: Dick Schoof in The Hague on June 3. Photographer: Laurens Van Putten/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Penn Wins Dismissal of Antisemitism Suit by Jewish Students
item.description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit against University of Pennsylvania filed by Jewish students over antisemitism, ruling they failed to show the Ivy League school engaged in intentional discrimination.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Students on the University of Pennsylvania campus in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US, on Friday, Dec. 8, 2023. Penn was sued by a pair of students who claim the campus was a hotbed of antisemitism even before Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7.

item.title: Lula Blasts US Threats to Impose Sanctions on Brazil Judge
item.description: President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva denounced US threats to impose sanctions on a Brazilian Supreme Court judge, saying it is “unacceptable” for the Trump administration to try to interfere in another country’s legal process.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: Doritos, M&Ms Could Be Forced to Include Warnings in Texas
item.description: A Texas bill on the verge of becoming law would require labels on packaged food from Skittles to Mountain Dew that warn about ingredients “not recommended for human consumption” by other countries.
item.dc:creator: Will Kubzansky, Rachel Cohrs Zhang

item.title: Bessent Says China Has a ‘Choice’ on Whether or Not to Be a Reliable Partner
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Beijing has a choice on whether or not to be a dependable partner with the rest of the world, reiterating that China needs to shift to a more consumption-led economy to help ease global imbalances.
item.dc:creator: Annmarie Hordern, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Starmer Weighs UK Military Request to Back 3.5% NATO Spend Goal
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer is considering a Ministry of Defence request to back NATO’s proposed new military spending target of 3.5% of national output by 2032, a major new pledge that would test the UK’s already stretched public finances.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Alex Wickham, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer speaks to British and Albanian troops during a visit to Berzite military museum in Tirana, Albania.

item.title: NATO Is Pushing Europeans for Fivefold Boost to Air Defenses
item.description: NATO is asking European member states to expand ground-based air-defense capabilities fivefold as the alliance races to fill a key gap in response to the threat of Russian aggression, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: IRIS-T SLM air defense systems in Panker, Germany. Photographer: Gregor Fischer/Getty Images

item.title: Kirchner’s Return Risks Dividing Opposition in Boon for Milei
item.description: Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner is back on Argentina’s political scene for the first time since President Javier Milei took office, set to challenge the libertarian and contest power within her own Peronist party in an upcoming local vote.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

item.title: Carney’s Budget Delay Adds to Economic Uncertainty in Canada, Analysts Say
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s decision to delay Canada’s budget until later this year increases economic uncertainty but isn’t likely to spark worries among investors, say a majority of economists in a Bloomberg survey.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg, Dana Morgan
